moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Nf3 g6: The fiachetto is probably the best structure against the London attack. This doesn't mean I won't play my favorite plan against it. The first thing to do is to block the action of a future black bishop... on f5! The black squared bishop will aim to a solid pawn wall (c3), and it is not dangerous itself.
moves.3. Bf4 Bg7 4. h3: This move is necessary so, in case of Af5, g4. Of course, the side-effect is to provide a square for the bsb in case of an early Nh5.
moves.4... d6 5. e3 O-O 6. g4: Af5 prevented. Some play Be6, here... and it is not as bad as it seems.
moves.6... b6: But black has the other right plan.
moves.7. c4: I decide to sacrify the pawn wall against the bsb by providing a block against the wsb with d5.
moves.7... Bb7 8. Nc3 Nbd7 9. Be2: Tempting him to try to exploit the pin over the f3 knight.
moves.9... Ne4: My plan should have been h4, here, trying to attack soon his king. This moves allows him to open my future castling on the queenside.
moves.10. Qc2 Nxc3: My queen move was bad. I cannot take with the queen, because of e5.
moves.11. bxc3 e6: Here, he could have played e5.
moves.12. Rh2: So I prevented it. The idea is to castle queenside (or Kd2, also possible) and get my rooks on his king. But it is not a straight-forward plan.
moves.12... d5 13. h4 dxc4 14. h5: I was almost forced to attack a bit too soon.
moves.14... b5 15. hxg6 hxg6:
I though he would have taken with the f7 pawn. 
Here, one of the variants I found interesting:

moves.16. Nh4:
A sac. I imagined that the queen in g6 should have guaranteed me compensation.

moves.16... c5 17. Nxg6: In a hurry to preserve the attack.
moves.18... Nf6 19. Bh6 Rf7: I didn't see Be4, that frees him from any danger. So I HAD to play the UGLY...
You see, he comes first. The right move here is Qg8+ and exchanging queens. But I am a piece under!
moves.25. exd4 Qf6: I didn't see here the threat Qf4... now, I tried a lot of ways to preserve my attack, but they doesn't work. Qg8+, Ke7, h7 would be a good try, but Qf4+ and then QxRh2 destroys me.
moves.26. Rf2 Qxg6: without the queen, my game is technically lost. The pawn itself is not enough to give me compensation.
moves.27. Rxg6 Rf6: No point it retire the rook, although I could have played Rg3... and lose my only "good" pawn.
moves.31. Bxf5 exf5 32. Rg2 Kf7: The advance of the d pawn doesn't lead me to recover the pawn. Again, I have to lose one tempo defending c3, and this gives him the time to go Rh8, and my pawn is lost. I calculated if in this case the d pawn could have brought me something, but it was not so... so I resigned.
